captions.text:
>>JOR EL: You will give the people an ideal
to strive towards.

They will race behind you, they will stumble,
they will fall.

But in time, they will 
join you in the sun.
In time, you will help them accomplish wonders.

comments.text:
You would think it was a Geoff Johns inspired Aquaman movie ( I wish) Jason 
Momoa will be awesome as Aquaman though so. I loved this movie. In some of 
the modern comic books there is one called the wanderer where it is about 
Superman just wandering the Earth lost in life until he finds out who he 
really is. This film takes a lot from the comic books especially Superman 
Earth One. It really does feel like a comic book Superman when Reeve's was 
more campy old fashioned 40's Superman that nobody can let go of.

comments.text:
I think it was the "hope" theme and atmosphere that the whole movie was 
lacking. It's so strong in this trailer and so weak in the actual film. I 
find it interesting how some music can change the feel and meaning of some 
footage, the solemn music and narration on this teaser gave the feeling of 
hope and epicness surrounding clark and his quest for finding his place on 
the world and encountering his destiny, sadly I feel like the movie barely 
touched into this journey.﻿

comments.author: BakaMania®

comments.text:
Amazing teaser... promised so much for the film, which sadly descended into 
the usual CGI borefest. For goodness sake hollywood, focus on depth of 
character, chemistry, story evolution... that give the audience a 
connection with the character and the film. Cavill is great, but make it a 
story, not a special effects bonanza. A character like superman has so much 
potential to be truly EPIC. A normal guy capable of world-changing feats, 
who is almost obliged to sacrifice himself for the planet... Not a CGI 
slugfest at a million miles per hour.﻿

comments.text:
My sentiments exactly. I like to go back and watch the MOS trailers every 
few months to remind myself what the movie should have been.

An alien orphan trying to fit in and find out his true purpose in life, 
dealing with loss, falling in love, making his decision not to kill, etc. 
Just a few of the themes that were brushed over in place of 'meaty punches'.

comments.text:
+Inglese29 This movie had a great combination between CGI and practical 
effects, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B7GShUYBqNo
We only had 30 minutes of action of it's 135 minutes of runtime, your are 
judging it because you didn't understood it.
comments.author: Kal-El fan 49

comments.text:
+Jeswin Abraham Gotta disagree, I don't want to patronise you but maybe 
you're too young to appreciate films that don't have the amount of CGI / 
explosions / general crash bang wallop that is typified by MOS. example: 
the original 3 star wars films compared to the last 3. First 3 were ten 
times better in my opinion, and the opinion of most other people i would 
say, although they still had lots of action. The trailer for MOS didn't 
feature any of the CGI heavy carnage and hinted at a film that would be 
'deep', which it wasn't. And for a film of this length, 20 
minutes of character development isn't much really. Sure there has to be 
some action and 'super' stuff, but this film went overboard and for my 
taste became just noisy and boring. The CGI was good, but that's to be 
expected given the budget... depends if you like CGI I guess. It's ok in 
small, effective doses but special effects shouldn't be the centrepiece of 
a film.
comments.author: Inglese29

comments.text:
What are you talking about? MOS had an awesome story. It showed you what it 
was like to be an alien in this planet isolated from everyone on a path to 
find out about ones self. I swear people who are hating on this movie 
contradicts themselves all over the place, I read on guy saying there is 
too much story and subplot in the first 20 minutes of the film alone and 
now you are saying it has none. Also what this film was promising was in 
depth look at what superman is capable of and it delivered that unlike the 
last superman. Also CGI bore fest? The CGI in this film was amazing and 
even haters have to admit that. Please don't compare Zack Snyders work to 
MrBay's. Cheers.
comments.author: Telos Supreme

comments.text:

comments.text: This is soooooo true
comments.author: DominicanMarine129

comments.text:
+busywl69 you're right on the money about everything you said. I know it 
will never happen but I would like to see batman on Netflix in the same

comments.author: algerae1984

comments.text:
+mathias holland I think they are finally starting to get it with what 
people want to see when they spend hard earned money to go to these IMAX 
screenings.  A lot of people weren't ready for man of steel, but the right 
audience was and that's all that matters.  I've had enough of him floating 
around doing hardly nothing, it was time for him to get that pretty suit 
dirty.  

I'm sure marvel will get spiderman right, although I do wonder what is 
right?  The to amazing movies were closer to the comic books, but the 
weighed the fun down every time they could and what spiderman was doing 
wasn't so 'amazing'.  Loved the chemistry between parker/gwen, but 
everything else just wasn't thought out right.  

I often wonder with so much great source material (comics, graphic novels, 
ect), why is it so hard for these guys to get certain characters right in 
the movies (punisher, spiderman, iron man solo films, ect) and tv. 
 Netflix's daredevil was amazing.  But Marvel seems to know what they are 
doing with all this.  Endless river of opportunity for marvel.  I think DC 
should be grittier, so I hope thats continues with this batman vs superman. 
 It will be interesting to see how they stretch a 5 second fight to 3 hours 
with audiances who just look at the 2 of them on paper.
comments.author: busywl69

comments.text: +mathias holland yeh, agreed
comments.author: kylo ren

comments.text:
+kylo ren Over use of action??? If it weren't for the action, we could've 
ended up with another career ruining movie like Superman Returns... a 
modern Superman flick that showcased his powers less than the originals! 
This is exactly what I expect from super powered beings throwing down...
comments.author: mathias holland

comments.text:
+kylo ren I could argue either side of this. It's best live action Superman 
I've ever seen, but the dumb moments are really egregious. For me, it 
wasn't the fight scenes that were overkill, it was everything to do with 
krypton. When Jor-EL dove off that tower and landed on the back of his 
dragon. I think other people in the theater may have heard me groan.
comments.author: Felix Ray

comments.text:

need to establish a base before you can really make something amazing

comments.author: N7Normandy117: DAWN OF JUSTICE LEAGUE

comments.text:
+busywl69 Completely agree. Spiderman is meant to be a fun character 
therefore he should be done as a fun a little campy character. Have those 
moments of darkness to keep the suspense and emotion but in general make a 
Spiderman film fun even for me who loves dark super hero movies more than 
the light ones doesn't want that to get in the way of respecting the 
character's lighter tones. All super heroes have different ways of coping 
with their traumas, with Spiderman it is making fun of his criminals like 
the bullies who bullied him in High School, but having fun with his powers 
which the amazing films did too. But still make it have dark moments so it 
is emotional, with Batman he becomes his anger and darkness, Batman should 
always be dark. With Superman saving people is what keeps his inner pain at 
bay etc.
comments.author: N7Normandy117: DAWN OF JUSTICE LEAGUE

comments.text:
They spent too much time on 'poor guy with the cool superpowers' angle in 
the raimi flicks.  I mean what was that 3rd one?  The recent 2 were more on

In raimi's films, he didnt hate being spider-man, only when it negatively

they did in the 2nd and 3rd movies.

 Fun.  Not great, but fun.  Raimi's looked better though.

comments.text:
Raimi's spider-man films werent depressing.... the ASM films were,

comments.author: DarkKnight2037

comments.text:
By the time they got done with the dark knight for those movies he was as 
depressing to watch as sam raimi's spiderman series.  Who wants to pay 
theater money to see your hero grinding bones in his knees and other 
geriatric stuff like that.
comments.author: busywl69

comments.text:
Also the dark knight batman was a slightly lighter take on the comic book 
Batman. In the comic books when batman beats up criminals there is blood 
everywhere, he breaks their bones and nearly kills criminals. In the dark 
knight he just hits them and they are just knocked out. Joker in the dark 
knight was a lot like Frank Miller's The Dark a Knight Returns graphic 
novel, that Joker was worse than Heath Ledger's Joker. Much more psychotic 
and ruthless. The only big difference with the movies is that in the comics 
and animated shows it is obvious Batman is a psychotic sociopath who has 
big issues letting go, he is the peak of human perfection psychically and 
mentally and is a master detective when the movie Batman just screams at 
criminals and he only wanted to be Batman so that he could take care of all 
crime in the city then stop being batman and be with Rachell. In the comics 
Bruce's rage is far greater than anything, the bat suit is like a freak of 
nature, he is Batman, Bruce Wayne is the mask. The real him is an obsessive 
compulsive madman who dresses up like a bat beating up a clown all night.
comments.author: N7Normandy117: DAWN OF JUSTICE LEAGUE

comments.text:
Really? I love this movie and I thought it was far more like the comics 
than Christopher Reeve's campy 40's Superman that people cannot seem to let 
go of. The modern comic book Superman is all about fighting cosmic beings 
like Darkseid, king of Apokalips, Brainiac the destroyer of Krypton. 
Superman is always getting his butt handed to him and feeling like an 
outcast, doubting himself and knowing his limits rather than the old golden 
age comic book superman who could lift the planet with ease. The comics are 
more like the movies now.
comments.author: N7Normandy117: DAWN OF JUSTICE LEAGUE

comments.text:
In final analysis, the film itself was lacking, but this teaser was one of 
the best ever made. Compare this to the Star Wars 7 teaser... this teaser 
has a strong theme, it displays a new take on Superman's origins alongside 
recognizable imagery, and it has a fantastic score accompanying Russell 
Crowe's inspiring narration. The Star Wars 7 trailer showcases two unknown 
characters and a series of familiar Star Wars icons which don't appear to 
be tied together in a central theme at all. If it were not for all the Star 
Wars rumors (or leaks), people would have no idea what to even make about 
that teaser.﻿

comments.author: Ben80316cp

comments.text:
1) the tone. Batman is supposed to be the dark, brooding, gritty, realistic 
and gothic super-hero. Superman is supposed to be optimistic, that's why he 
stands for all of the good things that we used to idolize (truth, justice, 
etc.)

2) character development. clark's desire to save people seems to come from 
nowhere, especially since the only father he knew in MoS his whole life 
told him to "maybe" let people die and told him not to save him from the 
tornado.

3) form. all of its problems aside, the Richard Donner Superman movies (I 
and his version of II) stick with people because, like Star Wars, they 
adhere to the old monomyth, the story of the epic hero conquering evil 
through great tribulations. Man of Steel has the "hero" becoming like the 
villain in order to conquer him.

4) image. Superman is always, ALWAYS, being likened to the God of the 
Judeo-Christian tradition. i remember back in late 2001 where one magazine 
actually ran an article that said "where was Superman on 9/11?" just as 
easily you could replace Superman with your choice of deity and the 
article's message (human heroes > fictitious ones) would have been 
unchanged. in light of that, and the Jesus imagery in this film, what does 
Man of Steel deliver about the notion of deities, what with Superman having 
the glowing red eyes when he uses heat vision, letting thousands of people 
die in massive collateral damage, killing his first foe and telling the US 
gov't that, despite showing that he will kill if forced (and let people die 
in the process), they should just "have faith" in him? i don't know, seems 
to give the same impression that the Noah movie made (and don't bring up 
Cyclops from the X-men: nobody likens Cyclops to God, not by any stretch of 
the imagination). i know most people probably don't believe in any god, so 
then why do we need to have yet ANOTHER film that is fixated on attacking 
the idea of God? we have so many, one would think nonreligious people have 
an undying god-hate fetish

5) the plot. why does Zod (who isn't the satan archetype of the Donner 
films, further pushing Man of Steel from the monomyth) choose earth above 
all other places to use his world engine, especially when there are other 
planets possibly more suitable? so that there is a conflict, you say? fine, 
i'll buy that. but why does Superman choose to, once again, let people die 
instead of telling them to go transform another planet? (in this case, 
unlike the collateral damage from before, it is willful. he says "Krypton 
had its chance" before destroying Zod's ship. it is a willful act that can 
easily be compared to genocide)

6) petty annoyances. Zod shouldn't have said "i will find him" four times 
in a row (even Terrence Stamp's campier moments weren't that silly). the 
reaction of the people of earth after being threatened by destruction by an 
alien/knowing that there are aliens was very weak and unrealistic. i love 
Amy Adams, but i can't stand what the director did: imo, the charm and 
charisma that i've seen her portray in her other roles is just not here

condensed: the tone was off and everything that Superman used to be was 
erased in favor of once again attacking the notion of God (see nu-Clash of 
the Titans, Legion, Noah, etc.)

comments.author: Jaime Meraz

comments.text:
I liked this movie, it's far and away my favorite live action Superman 
movie. It not only showcases his power, but his struggle to becoming the 
man of steel we know. Too many times I've heard how unreasonable it is that 
Supes is always able to do the right thing, but this movie shows his 
humanity and how hard it can be for him.

It's also very true to the comics with much of the content taken from 
Birthright, Earth 1, and the original Man of Steel relaunch in 1986. 
Superman killed? Yup, not his first time. Nearly every comic character has 
killed someone, hell Batman used to carry a gun. I'd love to hear you 
support your theory of how bad it was with facts because I thought it was 
fine. Only problem I had was the dialogue felt like everyone was giving a 
speech, but then Goyer isn't know for having fantastic dialogue.

Hell, if Supes can outlive Lobdell writing his Monthly issues, he can 
survive this.
